question_text: A 65-year old man with advanced prostate cancer is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of dyspnea and severe back pain. He rates his pain as an 8 on a 10 point scale. For the past 2 years, the patient failed to respond to multiple chemotherapy cycles. He was previously independent but now lives with his son and requires assistance with all activities of daily living. His son says that his father's condition “is deteriorating every day” and that he “cannot cope with the stress of taking care of him anymore.” The patient has had progressive loss of mobility and worsening pain for the past 6 months. During this time, he also has had decreased appetite, poor oral intake, and a 15-kg (33-lb) weight loss. He spends most of the day in bed and cannot tolerate walking without aid. Current medications include acetaminophen, oxycodone, and a fentanyl patch. He appears pale and malnourished. He is alert and fully oriented. Physical examination shows marked tenderness along the spine. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows multiple well-demarcated lesions in both lungs and in several vertebrae. The patient has no living will and says he wants to "die in peace." The physician, son, and the rest of the patient's family agree to start hospice care. Which of the following is the most significant factor that affects eligibility for hospice care in this patient?
content_preview: A 65-year old man with advanced prostate cancer is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of dyspnea and severe back pain. He rates his pain as an 8 on a 10 point scale. For the past 2 years, the patient failed to respond to multiple chemotherapy cycles. He was previously independent but now lives with his son and requires assistance with all activities of daily living. His son says that his father's condition “is deteriorating every day” and that he “cannot cope with the stress of taking care of him anymore.” The patient has had progressive loss of mobility and worsening pain for the past 6 months. During this time, he also has had decreased appetite, poor oral intake, and a 15-kg (33-lb) weight loss. He spends most of the day in bed and cannot tolerate walking without aid. Current medications include acetaminophen, oxycodone, and a fentanyl patch. He appears pale and malnourished. He is alert and fully oriented. Physical examination shows marked tenderness along the spine. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows multiple well-demarcated lesions in both lungs and in several vertebrae. The patient has no living will and says he wants to "die in peace." The physician, son, and the rest of the patient's family agree to start hospice care. Which of the following is the most significant factor that affects eligibility for hospice care in this patient?
hint: Hospice care eligibility is predominantly defined by the enrollment criteria of health insurers, including Medicare, Medicaid, and private insurance.
learning_objective: Recall the primary eligibility criterion for hospice care.

answers.explanation_why: Pain can affect a patient's functional status, qualify of life, and level of distress, all of which may influence a decision to pursue hospice care. However, pain is not a factor that directly affects eligibility for hospice care.

A patient's decision-making capacity may influence the decision to pursue hospice care, but it is not a factor that affects eligibility for hospice care. This patient is fully able to express his wishes and appears to have decision-making capacity at this time. If they are eligible, patients who do not have decision-making capacity may also be enrolled in hospice care by their legal decision-making proxy.

Hospice care can be provided in a private home setting, and the availability of family caregivers may influence the decision to pursue hospice care. However, this factor does not affect eligibility for hospice care.

To become eligible for hospice care, a patient must have an estimated life expectancy of < 6 months and decide to forgo therapies that have life-prolonging intent. Life expectancy can be assessed with the help of guidelines that measure the decline in clinical status, dependence on assistance, comorbidities, and certain disease-specific criteria (e.g. metastases in patients who have cancer). Patients may be discharged from hospice programs if their estimated life expectancy increases due to an improvement of their medical condition.

A living will is a legal document in which individuals describe their wishes regarding their care (e.g., to maintain, withhold, or withdraw life-sustaining treatment) should they become incapacitated. A patient is not required to have a living will to be eligible for hospice care.

question_text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. He has schizophrenia and advanced metastatic lung cancer. At a visit 3 weeks ago, the patient reported severe weight loss and loss of appetite. The physician recommended palliative percutaneous gastrostomy and explained the procedure as well as its benefits and possible complications. At the time, the patient objected to the procedure, stating that he did not wish to undergo any surgical procedures or life-prolonging interventions, including resuscitation. He designated his brother as the medical power of attorney. Current medications include quetiapine, hydromorphone-acetaminophen, and prednisolone. The patient appears cachectic and ill. He is 176 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (112 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m^2. He is alert and fully oriented. His vital signs are within normal limits. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 23/30. He has a flat affect. He denies auditory, visual, and tactile hallucinations. At the current visit, the patient appears to have changed his mind and wishes to undergo the procedure. His brother is present during the consultation and strongly disagrees with the patient's choice. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. He has schizophrenia and advanced metastatic lung cancer. At a visit 3 weeks ago, the patient reported severe weight loss and loss of appetite. The physician recommended palliative percutaneous gastrostomy and explained the procedure as well as its benefits and possible complications. At the time, the patient objected to the procedure, stating that he did not wish to undergo any surgical procedures or life-prolonging interventions, including resuscitation. He designated his brother as the medical power of attorney. Current medications include quetiapine, hydromorphone-acetaminophen, and prednisolone. The patient appears cachectic and ill. He is 176 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (112 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m2. He is alert and fully oriented. His vital signs are within normal limits. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 23/30. He has a flat affect. He denies auditory, visual, and tactile hallucinations. At the current visit, the patient appears to have changed his mind and wishes to undergo the procedure. His brother is present during the consultation and strongly disagrees with the patient's choice. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
hint: This patient wants to undergo an invasive surgical procedure with potential complications. It is important to reassess his decision-making capacity, especially because of his risk factors for impaired cognition.
learning_objective: Recognize the need to reassess decision-making capacity in patients with cognitive impairment and schizophrenia, and choose the appropriate response to confirm their understanding.

answers.content: "I know that you initially decided against the procedure. Are you sure that you want a gastrostomy?"
answers.explanation_why: Although the first part of this statement acknowledges the patient's wish via active listening (in keeping with the PEARLS model), it is followed by a close-ended question (i.e., the patient may respond with only a "yes" or "no”), which does not help to assess his decision-making capacity.

answers.content: "This must have been a difficult decision for you. Would you allow me to perform a preoperative assessment if this is your final choice?"
answers.explanation_why: This statement acknowledges the patient's feelings in an empathetic manner, in keeping with the PEARLS model. However, performing a preoperative examination is premature at this time because the patient's decision-making capacity has not yet been assessed.

answers.content: "I see that you have changed your mind. Could you explain to me in your own words what you understand about gastrostomy?"
answers.explanation_why: This patient's sudden change in the decision to undergo an invasive surgical procedure, in combination with mildly impaired cognition (Mini-Mental State Examination score of 23/30) and features of schizophrenia (e.g., flat affect), should prompt a reassessment of his decision-making capacity. The first part of this statement acknowledges the patient's wish via active listening, in keeping with the PEARLS model. The second part helps to assess his decision-making capacity, which includes evaluation of the patient's understanding of the situation and ability to use information to make a choice. Though this patient has articulated a choice, it is not yet clear if he is able to assimilate and process the potential outcomes of the proposed procedure, despite the physician's previous explanations. Standardized instruments, such as the MacArthur Competence Assessment Tool, are used to evaluate capacity and legal competence and involve a semi-structured interview with open-ended questions to explore the patient's reasoning.

answers.content: "Your brother seems to disagree with your choice. Could you talk to him first?"
answers.explanation_why: This patient has named his brother the medical power of attorney (POA), and it is reasonable for him to discuss his condition and preferences with his brother. The POA is tasked with making decisions for the patient if the patient lacks decision-making capacity. In this scenario, the patient's decision-making capacity has not yet been assessed.

answers.content: "This must be a difficult decision to make. Would you like to talk to another physician?"
answers.explanation_why: This statement acknowledges the patient's feelings in an empathetic manner, in keeping with the PEARLS model. However, referring this patient to another physician is not medically indicated at this time, and the patient has not requested to speak with another physician.

question_text: An 86-year-old man with metastatic pancreatic cancer is admitted to the hospital for palliative care and pain management. He had provided advanced directives against life-sustaining measures including resuscitation and intubation. Three days after admission, a nurse caring for the patient calls the on-call physician and says, “The patient has just died. His family have been in his room since yesterday and were aware that he would die soon.” The physician obtains necessary information from the nurse, reviews the patient's records, informs the attending physician responsible for the patient's care, and enters the patient's room with the nurse. After a self-introduction to the family, which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician?
content_preview: An 86-year-old man with metastatic pancreatic cancer is admitted to the hospital for palliative care and pain management. He had provided advanced directives against life-sustaining measures including resuscitation and intubation. Three days after admission, a nurse caring for the patient calls the on-call physician and says, “The patient has just died. His family have been in his room since yesterday and were aware that he would die soon.” The physician obtains necessary information from the nurse, reviews the patient's records, informs the attending physician responsible for the patient's care, and enters the patient's room with the nurse. After a self-introduction to the family, which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician?
hint: When family members are present, performing death pronouncements in a step-wise, solemn, and ritualized manner can provide the family with closure and allow them to grieve.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate statement for a physician to make when pronouncing death in the presence of family members.

answers.content: "Could you please confirm the identity of the patient for me? I would like to examine him in order to finalize his medical records."
answers.explanation_why: Confirming the identity of a deceased patient is a part of the process of death pronouncement. However, asking grieving family members to identify a deceased patient should be avoided (e.g., by using the hospital identification tag instead). Moreover, this response conceals the purpose of the physician's visit (i.e., pronouncing death) and is, therefore, inappropriate. Even if the deceased patient's family members have not yet been informed of the death, the physician should always address them in a clear, empathic manner and avoid euphemisms (e.g., “finalize his medical records”).

answers.content: "I am sorry for your loss. I am here to examine your loved one and pronounce his death."
answers.explanation_why:
This statement is the most appropriate way to address the family members of a deceased patient after an expected death. After a self-introduction, the physician should offer condolences with simple empathic statements (e.g., “I am sorry for your loss,” “This is a difficult time”) and clearly state the purpose of the visit. The physician should then invite the family to remain in the room and ask questions. If available, psychological and spiritual support services (e.g., grief counseling, chaplains) should be offered to the family. Subsequently, the death pronouncement process is begun and consists of confirming the patient's identity, examining for responses to tactile stimuli, looking for fixed and dilated pupils, and checking for at least one minute for the absence of each of the following: carotid pulses, chest movement, heart and breath sounds, and recordable blood pressure. The time at which the examination is concluded is the time at which death is confirmed (stated as the time of death). During this examination, the physician should refrain from talking too much in order to allow the family to grieve.

If the patient does not have an advance directive regarding organ or body donation and a forensic autopsy is not indicated, the family should be asked if they wish to have a clinical autopsy. If the family does not wish to have one, the physician can seek permission for organ or body donation if applicable. If a forensic autopsy is indicated, the local death investigation office (e.g., coroner) should be informed, even if the family does not consent. Following the declaration of death, the physician who pronounced the death should enter a death note in the patient's records; further death documentation should be performed by the physician(s) who were responsible for the patient's care.

answers.content: "I know what you are going through. How have you been coping with this situation so far?"
answers.explanation_why: Although showing empathy to a deceased patient's family members is appropriate, physicians should avoid overly personalized statements such as “I know what you are going through”. Moreover, the physician should begin by informing the family of the purpose of the visit rather than asking questions. The pronouncement of death is a time for quiet and grieving, and most families do not wish to engage in conversation at this time.

answers.content: "I have been informed that you were expecting him to pass away soon. Do you have any questions for me at this time?"
answers.explanation_why: Before pronouncing death in the presence of the patient's family members, it is important to ask them if they have any questions. However, the physician should clearly state the purpose of the visit before inviting the family to ask questions.

answers.content: "This must be very difficult for you. Could I ask you to step outside the room while I finish the examination?"
answers.explanation_why: Offering condolences with simple empathic statements such as “This must be very difficult for you” is an appropriate way to address the family members of a deceased patient. However, families should not be asked to leave the room during the death pronouncement but instead given the choice of whether they want to be present.

question_text: A 78-year-old woman receiving home hospice care for end-stage metastatic colon cancer is examined at her daughter's request because of a 2-week history of progressive breathlessness. She reports that her mother has been bedridden for the past 3 months and started sleeping in an upright position in the last few days. Two months ago, a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube was placed because the patient was unable to feed herself. For the past day, she refuses to drink water or to be fed through the PEG tube. Medications include morphine, magnesium hydroxide, metoclopramide, and dexamethasone. The patient appears cachectic. Pulse is 85/min, respiratory rate is 11/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. The skin overlying the PEG catheter appears well perfused with no tenderness to palpation and no purulent discharge. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's breathlessness?
content_preview: A 78-year-old woman receiving home hospice care for end-stage metastatic colon cancer is examined at her daughter's request because of a 2-week history of progressive breathlessness. She reports that her mother has been bedridden for the past 3 months and started sleeping in an upright position in the last few days. Two months ago, a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube was placed because the patient was unable to feed herself. For the past day, she refuses to drink water or to be fed through the PEG tube. Medications include morphine, magnesium hydroxide, metoclopramide, and dexamethasone. The patient appears cachectic. Pulse is 85/min, respiratory rate is 11/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. The skin overlying the PEG catheter appears well perfused with no tenderness to palpation and no purulent discharge. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's breathlessness?
hint: Terminally ill patients with end-stage cancer commonly experience breathlessness during their last weeks of life.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for terminal dyspnea in end-stage cancer patients.

answers.explanation_why: Supplemental oxygen is recommended for symptom relief in palliative care patients with dyspnea and hypoxemia. In nonhypoxemic patients, supplemental oxygen should not be used as there is no benefit over room air. Instead, airflow interventions (e.g., a hand-held fan) can be offered to the patient as supportive therapy.

Systemic opioids (e.g., morphine) are indicated in patients with severe terminal dyspnea that is not relieved by nonpharmacological interventions (e.g., a fan, body posture aids, breathing techniques). Opioids relieve dyspnea through various mechanisms, including altering central perception of dyspnea, reducing anxiety, and decreasing the respiratory drive. The opioid dose should be slowly titrated until the optimal risk-benefit ratio between efficacy and adverse effects (e.g., constipation, nausea, pruritus, bronchospasm, drowsiness) has been reached. Patients and caregivers should be informed about the benefits and safe use of opioid therapy, as well as treatment of adverse effects (e.g., stimulant laxatives for constipation).

Benzodiazepines (e.g., midazolam) are a second-line pharmacological treatment option in palliative care patients with dyspnea-related anxiety and/or persistent dyspnea. Treating anxiety may reduce the severity of dyspnea. However, this patient shows no signs of anxiety and has not yet received nonpharmacological or first-line pharmacological therapies. Furthermore, monotherapy with benzodiazepines is not routinely recommended for terminally ill patients with dyspnea.

Benzodiazepines are also used for palliative sedation, which may be initiated to relieve severe distress at the end of life in patients with refractory symptoms (e.g., breathlessness, pain), terminal agitation, or perceived discomfort. However, sedation should only be used after all other attempts to control or relieve symptoms have failed. The decision to start palliative sedation should be made under the guidance of a palliative care physician and/or a medical ethicist. Because the treatment induces unconsciousness and may hasten death, the plan should be discussed with the patient, caregivers, and/or family, who must give informed consent before sedation begins.

Diuretics, e.g., furosemide, are indicated to treat dyspnea in patients with pleural effusion due to congestive heart failure or pulmonary edema. However, this patient has no signs of an underlying condition and her dyspnea is likely caused by end-stage colon cancer.

Naloxone is indicated in patients with opioid-induced respiratory depression. Clinical features of opioid intoxication include a decreased respiratory rate, altered mental status, bilateral miosis, myoclonic jerks, and decreased bowel sounds. Although this patient is taking morphine and has a low respiratory rate, she does not present with any other features of opioid intoxication. Her dyspnea is likely caused by end-stage colon cancer, for which naloxone is not indicated.

question_text: A 62-year-old man is receiving hospice care in a nursing care facility because of end-stage metastatic pancreatic cancer that was diagnosed 6 months ago. The patient was previously independent but is now bedridden and requires assistance for all of his daily activities. The physician is concerned about the patient's well-being because he seems demoralized and does not interact with hospital staff or other patients. He never has visitors. When the physician inquires about his mood, the patient only replies, “I just want to be left alone and watch TV." The physician has passed by the patient's room on several occasions and noticed church services playing on his TV. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician to support the patient at this point?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man is receiving hospice care in a nursing care facility because of end-stage metastatic pancreatic cancer that was diagnosed 6 months ago. The patient was previously independent but is now bedridden and requires assistance for all of his daily activities. The physician is concerned about the patient's well-being because he seems demoralized and does not interact with hospital staff or other patients. He never has visitors. When the physician inquires about his mood, the patient only replies, “I just want to be left alone and watch TV." The physician has passed by the patient's room on several occasions and noticed church services playing on his TV. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician to support the patient at this point?
hint: Hospice care is an integral and holistic approach to end-of-life care, which aims to improve a patient's quality of life by addressing their physical, psychological, and spiritual needs.
learning_objective: Recognize the need to take a spiritual history in hospice care.

answers.content: Ask the hospice chaplain to visit the patient
answers.explanation_why: A hospice chaplain is a trained medical professional who can aid in caring for a patient's spiritual needs during the end-of-life process. Before asking the chaplain to visit the patient, the physician must first assess the patient's personal needs and beliefs.

answers.content: Check the patient's documentation to find out if he is religious
answers.explanation_why: Although identifying individuals who would benefit from spiritual care is important, medical records may not specify a patient's religious or spiritual beliefs and background. Furthermore, a patient may have spiritual beliefs that are not connected to a particular religion or may be affiliated with a religion without being a practicing member.

answers.content: Take a spiritual history of the patient
answers.explanation_why: Terminal illness can cause spiritual distress, which negatively affects physical and mental well-being (e.g., increased risk of depression, uncontrollable pain, anxiety). Health care professionals should assess a patient's spirituality and signs of associated distress by taking a spiritual history (e.g., asking the patient if they consider themself religious or about the importance of spirituality in their life). If the patient identifies as spiritual or religious and shows signs of spiritual distress, referral to a board-certified chaplain of their faith is advised. Chaplains can provide spiritual care, which includes attending to the terminally ill individual's spiritual and/or religious needs and beliefs, helping them to cope with their illness, and assisting in medical decisions (e.g., whether to continue life-sustaining treatments). This process also strengthens the physician-patient relationship while increasing patient satisfaction and overall quality of life.

answers.content: Assure the patient that the hospice program will help him feel better
answers.explanation_why: Hospice care aims to maximize a terminally ill patient's quality of life by addressing their physical, psychological, and spiritual needs. By simply reassuring the patient, the physician fails to identify and directly address his specific needs.

answers.content: Talk about their own spiritual beliefs to help the patient to open up
answers.explanation_why: Addressing a patient's spiritual needs is essential in hospice care. In order to do so, the physician should foster a caring, patient-centered environment. Initiating a conversation about one's own spiritual beliefs shifts focus away from the patient and could be perceived as proselytizing, which violates the patient's trust.

question_text: A 67-year-old woman, who receives home hospice care for end-stage glioblastoma multiforme, is examined at home at the request of her son. He is concerned about the number of medications she takes. Three weeks ago, she was admitted to the hospital for recurrent generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Two months ago, a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube was placed because the patient was unable to feed herself. Medical history is significant for hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, type 1 diabetes mellitus, insomnia, and major depressive disorder. Her current medications are fentanyl, mirtazapine, ramipril, dexamethasone, insulin lispro, insulin glargine, lamotrigine, metoclopramide, and atorvastatin. She appears ill. BMI is 18 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg. She is oriented to person but not to place or time. Her serum glucose concentration is 197 mg/dL. Which of the following medications is most appropriate to discontinue at this time?
content_preview: A 67-year-old woman, who receives home hospice care for end-stage glioblastoma multiforme, is examined at home at the request of her son. He is concerned about the number of medications she takes. Three weeks ago, she was admitted to the hospital for recurrent generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Two months ago, a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube was placed because the patient was unable to feed herself. Medical history is significant for hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, type 1 diabetes mellitus, insomnia, and major depressive disorder. Her current medications are fentanyl, mirtazapine, ramipril, dexamethasone, insulin lispro, insulin glargine, lamotrigine, metoclopramide, and atorvastatin. She appears ill. BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg. She is oriented to person but not to place or time. Her serum glucose concentration is 197 mg/dL. Which of the following medications is most appropriate to discontinue at this time?
hint: Deprescription of medications that are administered for primary or secondary prevention is recommended in most patients receiving end-of-life care.
learning_objective: Choose medications to discontinue in end-of-life care based on patient comfort and prognosis.

answers.explanation_why: Analgesics, such as fentanyl, are commonly used to treat chronic pain in patients with cancer. Although analgesics can cause adverse events (e.g., cognitive impairment and delirium), these medications manage pain and promote the patient's quality of life, which is the priority in palliative care. A different medication can be discontinued without affecting quality of life.

In patients with type I diabetes mellitus, glycemic control should be maintained to avoid complications (e.g., ketoacidosis), even at the end of life. However, patients in palliative care have a greater risk of hypoglycemia than hyperglycemia. These patients benefit from a simplified antidiabetic regimen and less strict glycemic control, which can be achieved with long-acting insulins (e.g., insulin glargine). Short-acting insulin (e.g., insulin lispro) administration, which requires a painful fingerstick test to obtain glucose measurements, can be discontinued.

Antidepressants, such as mirtazapine, are often used to manage major depressive disorder and insomnia in patients in palliative care. The Beers criteria, which are typically considered when managing medications in patients with polypharmacy, advise against using ≥ 3 CNS-active drugs (e.g., antidepressants, antiepileptic drugs, benzodiazepines, opioids) because of the risk of sedation, cognitive impairment, and delirium. Although these criteria apply generally to patients over 65 years of age, they do not apply to those receiving end-of-life care. Discontinuing mirtazapine is likely to decrease this patient's quality of life.

When life expectancy is decreased, there is little benefit from drugs administered for long-term cardiovascular protection such as antihypertensives (e.g., ramipril), statins, and low-dose aspirin. For patients with diabetes mellitus, a simplified antidiabetic regimen and less strict glycemic control are recommended; short-acting insulins can be discontinued. Drug interactions, the risk of adverse events, and the patient burden should all be considered when assessing medications for deprescription. Medications that should generally be continued to maximize patient comfort include analgesics, antiemetics, antidepressants, anxiolytics, and antiseizure agents.

Because some patients do not tolerate oral intake, routes of medication administration should be adapted in the palliative care setting. In general, less invasive routes of administration (e.g., subcutaneous, transdermal) are preferred.

The Beers criteria, which are typically considered when managing medications in patients with polypharmacy, advise against using ≥ 3 CNS-active drugs (e.g., antidepressants, antiepileptic drugs, benzodiazepines, opioids) because of the risk of sedation, cognitive impairment, and delirium. Although these criteria apply generally to patients over 65 years of age, they do not apply to those receiving end-of-life care. Because this patient has a recent history of seizures, anticonvulsants such as lamotrigine should not be discontinued to avoid further seizures and maintain this patient's quality of life.

question_text: An 88-year-old woman with end-stage chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is being discharged from the hospital after being admitted with a COPD exacerbation for the fourth time in 5 months. During three of the previous hospitalizations, trials of bilevel positive airway pressure were unsuccessful, and she was intubated. Although she did not require intubation during this admission, she confides to the physician before discharge that she is tired of going to the intensive care unit and does not want to be intubated in the future. The physician discusses what matters most to her, and she says it is her independence. She understands that she could be in a situation in which she may die without intubation and says, “I’ve lived a long life. I’m not afraid of dying. I just want to be comfortable when the time comes.” She clearly states that she does not want to be intubated again or to be resuscitated. The physician determines that the patient has the mental capacity to make this decision. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician to ensure that all future care providers provide care in line with the patient's preferences?
content_preview: An 88-year-old woman with end-stage chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is being discharged from the hospital after being admitted with a COPD exacerbation for the fourth time in 5 months. During three of the previous hospitalizations, trials of bilevel positive airway pressure were unsuccessful, and she was intubated. Although she did not require intubation during this admission, she confides to the physician before discharge that she is tired of going to the intensive care unit and does not want to be intubated in the future. The physician discusses what matters most to her, and she says it is her independence. She understands that she could be in a situation in which she may die without intubation and says, “I’ve lived a long life. I’m not afraid of dying. I just want to be comfortable when the time comes.” She clearly states that she does not want to be intubated again or to be resuscitated. The physician determines that the patient has the mental capacity to make this decision. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician to ensure that all future care providers provide care in line with the patient's preferences?
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate documentation for a patient who does not wish to be intubated in the future.

answers.content: Record “Do not resuscitate and do not intubate” in the problem list and orders in her chart
answers.explanation_why: Recording resuscitation preferences in the patient’s problem list and placing an order in her chart would not adequately address her wishes, because they may not be seen by all of her providers. Orders placed in a hospital chart are only valid for that admission in that hospital and would expire when she is discharged.

answers.content: Document the discussion in the encounter note, and alert the patient's primary care provider
answers.explanation_why: Although documenting her wishes in the encounter note and informing her primary care provider (PCP) about the discussion is appropriate, these interventions alone would not be adequate. The documentation in the encounter note would not easily transfer with the patient when she leaves the hospital, and informing her PCP would not ensure that all of her providers are made aware of her treatment preferences.

answers.content: Complete a living will with the patient and have it notarized
answers.explanation_why: A living will may be completed by the patient to describe her wishes for end-of-life care. However, even if it is notarized, a living will is not considered a medical order and is not readily usable or accessible by emergency medical services or first responders to determine which treatments to provide in an emergency. Moreover, a living will is an advance directive that should be completed by the patient, not the physician.

answers.content: Consult the palliative care team and inform them about the patient's preferences
answers.explanation_why: Palliative care consultation for the broader goal of assisting with goals-of-care conversations, symptom management, and support in this patient with end-stage COPD is appropriate and indicated as part of her care plan. However, the best person to document the patient’s preferences regarding life-sustaining therapy is the clinician who has had the conversation and who already knows the patient well. Palliative care clinicians generally do not need to be consulted to complete a standardized form for end-of-life care directives when the patient can articulate their wishes regarding life-sustaining treatment.

answers.content: Complete a portable orders for life-sustaining therapy form with the patient
answers.explanation_why:
This patient has clearly stated her wishes regarding intubation and resuscitation, and there is no concern about her mental capacity to make this decision. The best way to document her preferences is to complete a portable orders for life-sustaining therapy (POLST) form, which turns a patient’s care preferences into specific medical orders that easily travel with the patient across the healthcare system and can be directly used in a medical emergency. The POLST form is completed by the patient's healthcare provider and is signed by both the provider and the patient (or healthcare proxy if the patient does not have decision-making capacity). Regulations vary by state regarding which providers can complete POLST forms, and may include physicians, nurse practitioners, and physician assistants. In some US states, POLST is known by medical orders for life-sustaining treatment (MOLST), physician orders for scope of treatment (POST), or another similar term. One copy of the POLST form should be retained by the patient or healthcare proxy, ideally in a place that is easily accessible in the case of an emergency, and another copy remains in a prominent place in the patient’s medical records. The POLST form can be changed by a healthcare provider according to the patient’s or healthcare proxy’s wishes.

A living will, on the other hand, is a legal document outlining a patient's preferences in a broad range of potential future scenarios in which they cannot make decisions due to incapacitation. Living wills are prepared by the patient and can guide healthcare providers but are not medical orders and are not easily portable across different care settings.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy with advanced Duchenne muscular dystrophy is hospitalized for worsening dysphagia and significant weight loss. His medical history is significant for progressive respiratory decline and severe scoliosis, and he currently uses non-invasive ventilation at night. Due to the severity of his condition, he and his parents previously agreed on a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) status via a portable order for life-sustaining treatment. Endoscopy cannot be performed because of severe scoliosis and surgical placement of a gastrostomy tube is deemed necessary to provide palliative nutritional support. During a preoperative review, the anesthesiologist notes the existing DNR order and expresses concern about potential complications during anesthesia that may require resuscitative measures. In addition to obtaining informed consent from the parents and assent from the patient for the procedure, which of the following is the most appropriate action regarding the patient's DNR order?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy with advanced Duchenne muscular dystrophy is hospitalized for worsening dysphagia and significant weight loss. His medical history is significant for progressive respiratory decline and severe scoliosis, and he currently uses non-invasive ventilation at night. Due to the severity of his condition, he and his parents previously agreed on a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) status via a portable order for life-sustaining treatment. Endoscopy cannot be performed because of severe scoliosis and surgical placement of a gastrostomy tube is deemed necessary to provide palliative nutritional support. During a preoperative review, the anesthesiologist notes the existing DNR order and expresses concern about potential complications during anesthesia that may require resuscitative measures. In addition to obtaining informed consent from the parents and assent from the patient for the procedure, which of the following is the most appropriate action regarding the patient's DNR order?
hint: Do-not-resuscitate (DNR) orders are written when both the treating clinician and the patient (or surrogate decision maker) agree that the patient would not benefit from attempted resuscitation because it would only prolong the time to death.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate protocol for handling do-not-resuscitate orders in an operative setting.

answers.content: Revoke the existing DNR order to perform the procedure
answers.explanation_why: This action limits the patient's and surrogate decision-maker's autonomy by assuming knowledge of what they want.

answers.content: Complete a DNR order specific to the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Although DNR orders preclude resuscitation in the case of spontaneous cardiopulmonary arrest, they do not limit the use of other therapeutic interventions, including surgery. Anesthesia inherently increases hemodynamic abnormalities that may result in cardiopulmonary arrest, and many routine anesthetic procedures, such as intubation and mechanical ventilation, could be classified as resuscitative. Consequently, most DNR orders cannot be maintained in the operative setting. When a patient with a DNR order requires a surgical procedure, the most appropriate step is to complete a procedure-specific DNR. Historically, DNR orders have been automatically suspended during procedures, but this practice limits patients’ autonomy by assuming knowledge of what they want. Currently, a process called “required reconsideration” in which the patient or surrogate, the surgeon, and the anesthesiologist revisit the DNR order for the perioperative setting during the informed consent process. Older children and adolescents should be included in discussions about their DNR orders and assent to DNR decisions to the extent that they are developmentally capable of doing so. Together, these individuals should discuss overall patient care goals and specific potential interventions that may be required. They should also define when the perioperative period officially ends and the preceding DNR order goes back into effect.

answers.content: Cancel the procedure to comply with the DNR order
answers.explanation_why: Although DNR orders preclude resuscitation in the case of spontaneous cardiopulmonary arrest, they do not limit the use of other therapeutic interventions, including surgery.

answers.content: Maintain the existing DNR order during the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Anesthesia inherently increases hemodynamic abnormalities that may result in cardiopulmonary arrest, and many routine anesthetic procedures, such as intubation and mechanical ventilation, could be classified as resuscitative. Consequently, most DNR orders cannot be maintained in the operative setting.

question_text: An 85-year-old woman with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, a history of stroke, and moderate dementia is hospitalized for a COPD exacerbation. This is her fourth admission in the past year. When she is at home, her 50-year-old daughter and 48-year-old son care for her with the assistance of visiting nurses and home health aides. Respiratory failure occurs during the current hospitalization, requiring intubation and admission to the intensive care unit (ICU). The patient becomes delirious and develops ventilator-associated pneumonia, requiring broad-spectrum antibiotics. Ten days after admission, the patient improves and is moved out of the ICU, but she remains persistently delirious despite appropriate interventions and is unable to meaningfully participate in rehabilitation. The patient does not have a designated healthcare proxy. The physician initiates a discussion with the family about the goals of care to inform discharge planning. The daughter wishes to transfer her mother to a skilled nursing facility, but the son disagrees and wants her to be discharged home. Which of the following is the most appropriate remark to continue the discussion with the patient's children?
content_preview: An 85-year-old woman with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, a history of stroke, and moderate dementia is hospitalized for a COPD exacerbation. This is her fourth admission in the past year. When she is at home, her 50-year-old daughter and 48-year-old son care for her with the assistance of visiting nurses and home health aides. Respiratory failure occurs during the current hospitalization, requiring intubation and admission to the intensive care unit (ICU). The patient becomes delirious and develops ventilator-associated pneumonia, requiring broad-spectrum antibiotics. Ten days after admission, the patient improves and is moved out of the ICU, but she remains persistently delirious despite appropriate interventions and is unable to meaningfully participate in rehabilitation. The patient does not have a designated healthcare proxy. The physician initiates a discussion with the family about the goals of care to inform discharge planning. The daughter wishes to transfer her mother to a skilled nursing facility, but the son disagrees and wants her to be discharged home. Which of the following is the most appropriate remark to continue the discussion with the patient's children?
hint: Many older patients with advanced illness have progressive functional dependence and an increasing need for caregiver support. Advance care planning is an important part of caring for such patients. This patient with delirium superimposed on dementia currently does not have decision-making capacity.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate approach to engage with family members who disagree on a discharge plan.

answers.content: "Keeping your mother in the hospital unnecessarily increases her risk for infection."
answers.explanation_why: This remark regarding the risk of infection associated with hospitalization is more likely to create confrontation and pressure family members, rather than foster an open and empathetic discussion about the patient's care.

answers.content: "What problems have you noticed at nursing facilities you’ve visited?"
answers.explanation_why: Specific questions that ask family members to express their concerns about quality of care, level of care, or specific facilities should be deferred until the family’s prognostic awareness is assessed, so that clinicians can ensure families have the information they need to engage in shared decision-making.

answers.content: "What is your understanding of how your mother is doing?"
answers.explanation_why:
It is important to continue the discussion with all involved caregivers (in this case, both the son and the daughter). A good way to start is by asking family members how they think the patient is doing. This allows the clinician to explore the family’s understanding of the patient’s illness and to identify any disparities in understanding the patient's prognosis that might be the cause of disagreement among family members. Care should be person-centered (i.e., aligned with the patient’s goals) to avoid both overtreatment and undertreatment of symptoms and based on the principle of substituted judgment. However, specific questions about the patient's goals of care should be deferred until the family’s prognostic awareness is assessed, so that clinicians can ensure families have the information they need to engage in shared decision-making regarding the next steps.

During advance care planning, it is also important to identify the appropriate legal surrogate decision-maker appointed by the patient. If no one has been appointed, as in this scenario, the physician should help the family assign someone to be a healthcare proxy. These steps can help prevent conflicts in the future. In addition, family members should be assessed for caregiver fatigue and should receive support for that as needed. In this particular case, the clinician should also talk with the family about referral to palliative medicine and explore hospice eligibility for this patient.

answers.content: "What were your mother's goals for her care?"
answers.explanation_why: Specific questions that ask family members about the patient's goals of care should be deferred until the family’s prognostic awareness is assessed, so that clinicians can ensure families have the information they need to engage in shared decision-making.

answers.content: "Have you been unhappy with the quality of your mother’s care?"
answers.explanation_why: Specific questions that ask family members to express their concerns about quality of care should be deferred until the family’s prognostic awareness is assessed, so that clinicians can ensure families have the information they need to engage in shared decision-making.

question_text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at home. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated by paramedics, but he remains unresponsive on arrival. His family says he appeared healthy on the previous day. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. He has no history of substance use and is not married. Physical examination shows a comatose man who is intubated and mechanically ventilated. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg, and respirations are controlled by the ventilator. He has fixed, dilated pupils, absent corneal and gag reflexes, and no spontaneous movements. Apnea testing confirms the absence of spontaneous respirations. The attending physician discloses the diagnosis of brain death to the family and gives some time to process the information. In a follow-up conversation, the physician addresses the topic of organ donation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at home. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated by paramedics, but he remains unresponsive on arrival. His family says he appeared healthy on the previous day. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. He has no history of substance use and is not married. Physical examination shows a comatose man who is intubated and mechanically ventilated. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg, and respirations are controlled by the ventilator. He has fixed, dilated pupils, absent corneal and gag reflexes, and no spontaneous movements. Apnea testing confirms the absence of spontaneous respirations. The attending physician discloses the diagnosis of brain death to the family and gives some time to process the information. In a follow-up conversation, the physician addresses the topic of organ donation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
hint: There are standardized processes for donor candidates who did not explicitly decline to donate organs.
learning_objective: Recognize key principles and requirements for organ donation in clinical practice.

answers.content: Request approval from the hospital ethics committee before proceeding
answers.explanation_why: Although the ethics committee may be involved in complex or disputed cases, its approval is not necessary for standard organ procurement procedures once brain death has been declared.

answers.content: Wait for a mandatory 24-hour period after brain death is declared before proceeding
answers.explanation_why: There is no mandatory waiting period between brain death and the initiation of the organ procurement process. Once brain death is confirmed, the patient is legally dead, and organ procurement procedures may proceed following established protocols. Prolonging the interval without a specific clinical or legal reason may reduce organ viability and is not a standard procedural step in organ donation protocols.

answers.content: Notify the local organ procurement organization for evaluation
answers.explanation_why: Federal regulations and hospital policy require that all potential organ donors be reported to a local organ procurement organization (OPO) as soon as brain death is established or imminent, unless the deceased patient has specifically declined to become a donor (e.g., in an advance directive). The OPO is responsible for evaluating medical suitability and discussing organ donation with the family. Physicians and hospital staff should not initiate the process for donation themselves (e.g., by obtaining consent), as this may result in conflicts of interest and reduce consent rates. OPO staff are specially trained to provide support, address questions, and facilitate the process ethically and sensitively. Early notification preserves organ viability and ensures that the process respects medical, ethical, and legal standards.

answers.content: Proceed only if the patient had a documented donor card
answers.explanation_why: Documented donor status is helpful but not required to initiate the process of organ donation. While a documented donor card or registration in a donor registry is legally binding in many states, organ donation evaluation should proceed even if such documentation is not available. In many cases, family members or legally authorized representatives may make decisions about donation in the absence of documented donor status, provided that other requirements and protocols are followed.

answers.content: Obtain written consent for organ donation from the patient's mother
answers.explanation_why: Written consent for organ donation may sometimes be required from the next of kin, depending on state law and the patient’s documented wishes. However, the process for obtaining and validating consent is standardized and typically involves designated professionals who are trained in these sensitive discussions.
